These include: age - alopecia areata occurs most frequently between ages 15 and 30, although it can occur at any age; family history - if someone else in your family has alopecia areata, you are more likely to develop it; stress - stressful events such as divorce, childbirth or death of a loved one may trigger alopecia areata; race - African Americans are at greater risk for alopecia areata; autoimmune diseases - alopecia areata may be associated with other autoimmune disorders such as lupus, thyroid disease or vitiligo.

There is no known cure for alopecia areata, so treatment is focused on alleviating symptoms and managing the condition. Some strategies for managing the condition include steroid injections and immunosuppressant drugs. Topical treatments such as minoxidil may also help to stimulate hair growth. In severe cases of alopecia areata, a hair transplant may be recommended.

Chronic kidney disease is a progressive loss of kidney function that is not reversible. It occurs slowly over time, so individuals may not experience any symptoms for years. As the kidneys continue to lose function, they are no longer able to filter waste products from the blood, causing waste products to build up in the bloodstream. These waste products can affect many organs in the body and may result in swollen feet or ankles, fatigue, nausea, loss of appetite, and confusion.

Diagnosis of chronic kidney disease begins with a simple blood test that checks for the presence of creatinine, which is a waste product filtered out by the kidneys. In addition, a blood test to check for glomerular filtration rate (GFR) can be used to assess kidney function. Other tests may include a urinalysis, imaging tests such as ultrasounds or X-rays, and a kidney biopsy.

Chronic kidney disease is usually treated by slowing its progression. There are many medications and treatments available for chronic kidney disease that help control symptoms, slow down the progression of the disease, and even reverse some of the damage caused by kidney disease. These include blood pressure medications, medications to decrease swelling, medications to lower phosphorous levels, vitamin D supplements, medications to improve red blood cell production, and dialysis. In advanced cases, a person may need a kidney transplant.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) occurs when a person's kidneys lose the ability to filter waste products from the blood. CKD can be caused by many things, including high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, smoking and heredity. Other factors that increase the risk of developing CKD include age, gender and race. African Americans are more likely than white people to develop CKD. Hispanic Americans are more likely to have CKD than non-Hispanic whites. Men are more likely to have CKD than women. People with diabetes are more likely to have CKD than those without diabetes.

There are five stages of chronic kidney disease. Stage 1 means that you have normal kidney function. In stage 2, your glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is between 90 and 89 mL/min/1.73m2. Stage 3 is classified as mild chronic kidney disease, as your GFR is between 60 and 59 mL/min/1.73m2. In stage 4, your GFR is between 30 and 59 mL/min/1.73m2 and your kidneys are no longer working properly. Stage 5 is classified as severe chronic kidney disease, as your GFR is less than 30 mL/min/1.73m2.

Chronic kidney disease is progressive, meaning it gets worse over time. There are many things that people can do to help slow its progression. These include maintaining a healthy weight, getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, getting regular exercise, managing your blood pressure, and monitoring your blood sugar level. It's also important to follow the advice of your doctor regarding lifestyle changes and medications.

The symptoms of Pellagra include: Skin lesions, especially on the palms and soles. Itching. Swelling and redness of the mouth. Diarrhea, nausea and vomiting. Depression. Fatigue. Loss of appetite. Difficulty sleeping. Muscle weakness. Irritability. Mental problems such as delusions and hallucinations.

Pellagra is a disease caused by a deficiency in vitamin B3, or niacin, which is found in meat and other animal products. It is most commonly seen in malnourished populations, such as those living in poverty in underdeveloped countries. In these regions, diets tend to consist of corn and rice, which are not good sources of vitamin B3. As a result, many people in these communities develop pellagra.

The primary treatment for pellagra is to increase vitamin B3 (niacin) intake. This can be done by increasing consumption of foods rich in niacin or taking a niacin supplement. Niacin deficiency is extremely rare in developed nations due to fortification of many staple foods.

Pellagra is caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) in the diet. It was once a common problem in the U.S., especially among poor populations, but it is now rare because of fortified grains, flours and cornmeal. To avoid developing this disease, individuals should make sure to eat plenty of foods high in niacin, such as fish, meat, poultry, eggs, legumes and whole grains. They should also try to limit the consumption of alcohol, as this can lead to a niacin deficiency.

Niacin deficiency, also known as Pellagra, is a condition that results from a lack of niacin, also called vitamin B3. It was first described in 1905, in Argentina, where it was found that poorly fed people suffered from skin disorders, diarrhea and mental problems. In 1937, the American Journal of Dermatology reported the case of a woman who developed all of these symptoms due to her dietary intake of cornmeal, which contains no niacin. Niacin is found in meats, fish, eggs and whole grains, so those who eat a balanced diet rarely develop Pellagra.

If Pellagra is left untreated, it can result in a wide variety of health problems. These include mental confusion, depression, dermatitis, diarrhea and anemia. Additionally, individuals suffering from Pellagra are at risk of developing heart disease. In some cases, death can result if the condition is not treated.

Varicose veins are enlarged and dilated blood vessels near the surface of the skin. They are often raised above the surface of the skin and appear blue or dark purple in color. These veins are commonly found on the legs and feet. They may be painful, itchy and sometimes cause swelling.

Varicose veins can be diagnosed with a physical examination of the legs and feet, along with an evaluation of the medical history. An ultrasound test, called a Doppler test, can also help determine the location and extent of the problem. If varicose veins are causing discomfort or other problems, the doctor may recommend additional tests, such as an x-ray, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan or a venous duplex ultrasound. These tests can provide images of the veins in the legs and show if any blood clots are present.

Varicose veins are enlarged and dilated blood vessels that are usually blue, purple or dark reddish-brown in color. These veins can appear anywhere on the body, but are most commonly seen on the legs. Varicose veins can be caused by weakened valves in the veins, or by obstructions to the flow of blood in the vein. Symptoms of varicose veins include swelling, heaviness and achiness in the legs, skin discoloration and itching, and sometimes ulcers or sores on the legs. If left untreated, varicose veins can lead to leg cramps, leg ulcers and venous insufficiency, which occurs when the veins cannot return blood to the heart.

Treatment for varicose veins depends on the severity of the problem. In cases where the veins are not causing any problems, treatment is not necessary. However, if the veins are causing discomfort or pain, a medical professional can provide a number of different treatments. These include sclerotherapy, laser therapy and endovenous thermal ablation. In cases where the veins are very large, the medical professional may recommend a procedure called stripping and ligation. This procedure involves cutting out and tying off the vein so that it cannot return blood to the heart.

Varicose veins occur when the valves inside the veins no longer work properly. When this happens, the vein cannot return blood back to the heart, so the blood pools in the veins and causes them to swell. There are many risk factors that increase the chance of developing varicose veins. These include obesity, pregnancy, family history of varicose veins, smoking, age and occupations that require prolonged standing or sitting.

Varicose veins can be prevented with lifestyle changes that promote circulation in the legs. These include walking regularly, wearing comfortable shoes and not sitting or standing in the same position for long periods of time. It is also important to lose weight if you are overweight. If these lifestyle changes do not help, your doctor may recommend compression stockings, which provide support to the leg veins, and elevating your feet while resting.

The symptoms of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) vary from person to person and can include breast tenderness, irritability, bloating, headaches, cramps, fatigue, depression, trouble sleeping, acne and increased sensitivity to cold. Some women experience no symptoms at all. It is estimated that between 50 percent and 80 percent of menstruating women experience PMS to some degree. The exact cause of PMS is not known, but it is believed to be due to fluctuations in hormone levels. PMS is thought to be related to changes in estrogen, progesterone and serotonin levels during the second half of the menstrual cycle.

Premenstrual syndrome, or PMS, is a complex group of physical and emotional symptoms that occurs in some women during the luteal phase of their menstrual cycle (the period of time between ovulation and the start of the next menstrual period). These symptoms may include breast tenderness, bloating, cramps, irritability, depression, headaches and fatigue. PMS is diagnosed based on the presence of symptoms, which must occur at least once per month, and last for at least a few days. The symptoms must also not be due to another medical condition.

There are many treatment options available for premenstrual syndrome (PMS), including lifestyle changes, medications, and alternative therapies. Lifestyle changes that may help include exercising regularly, reducing stress, eating healthy and getting plenty of rest. Some medications used to treat PMS include anti-inflammatory drugs, hormonal contraceptives, and antidepressants. Alternative therapies such as acupuncture, massage therapy, and yoga may also help alleviate some of the symptoms associated with PMS.

Premenstrual syndrome, or PMS, affects up to 75% of women at some point in their lives. Although the exact cause of PMS is not known, hormonal changes in the body during menstruation appear to be responsible for the symptoms of PMS. Other risk factors associated with PMS include having a family history of depression, anxiety disorders and/or PMS; being underweight; and smoking cigarettes. Women who are overweight and those who have high levels of estrogen in their bodies may also be more likely to experience PMS.

Premenstrual syndrome, commonly known as PMS, is a group of physical and emotional symptoms that some women experience before menstruation begins. These symptoms can range from mild to severe and can interfere with daily life activities such as working, studying, sleeping and enjoying time with family and friends. The symptoms of PMS can include breast tenderness, bloating, fatigue, headaches, irritability and depression. While the exact cause of PMS is unknown, it is thought to be due to hormonal changes that occur before menstruation. Treatment for PMS depends on the severity of symptoms and can include lifestyle changes, dietary modifications and medication.

While there is no cure for premenstrual syndrome (PMS), there are some things women can do to alleviate symptoms. These include reducing stress, eating healthy foods, exercising regularly, avoiding alcohol and smoking, getting plenty of sleep, and talking with a doctor about any medications that may help. Some women find relief with over-the-counter pain relievers, while others find herbal remedies to be helpful. In addition, some women may need prescription medication to control PMS symptoms.
